label: Letter 1 from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, March 15, 1943
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding how unhappy she is to be separated from him and apologizing for being irrational. Gertrude continues to discuss the business and troubles in managing Medway Plantation’s affairs.

March I5th '45
Sidney Darling,
In answer to your number ? March 8th-
I am glad you get the United States News. I saw Freddie Orschner
today outside the building and we had a long talk. He is getting fed up r
with desk work and wants to go back to newspaper reporting at the frontt.
He gave me to beleive he was going to leave this nut factory soon.
Next week he is off for New Urleans and hoped to see Armant down there.
1 have heard nothing furthur from Armant and do not know what his plans
are or how they have developed. _ '
People who have been trying to get off to the fronts
from this officeare stlllhere. No one eber seems to get off anywhere.
There is so much friction- jealousles etc. 1 beleive the war will be
over in H.A. before a single office force arrives. _
Now that I am back at my 'desk 'L feel as though 1 had
I never been away.It all seems so natural and routine.
Jy flight up with my guests yesterday was super. Terribly
fast, and perfect flying. We took a ride in the morning as we had
done every day and we poked along in the sunshine and purred like
cats. The Field Liarshal really looked rested from his trip and so
did we all. _ -
Hr`Lowndes came to dinner the last night and told some
heayenly tales- Une about the negroe who wanted to know how much
income tax he should pay because he had 4 wives. "[number]3 uncommon Law, and
I Church Law", He was very entertaining with that wonderful drawl
and the field Marshal told some amusing ones too. We all longed fpr
I you and wished you had been there with us. That night some stray
cows really wrecked our sleep by clanking up the drive way with cow bells
crashing and preceded to munch grass by the dark room,Such a racket you
have never heard, I got up at 3,30 to chase them.away and they left f
for a bit wnile L got back to sleep.again ,but ebidently they returned
and nobody closed an eye. It was a shame but so typical dont you think ?
I did not have that frustrated feeling as 1 did not try
_ to do anything or be efflcient.I felt however the place was shut in,
The flowers were not in bloom yet,yet l caught a tick that itches me
now like the devil. It all had great charm,'13he negroes were pleasant
a nd nice and everything looked a bit shoddy and run down. I guess
we all were so weary we did n't care at all] but -L think the -Ullls had
a bit of a shock there was no lawn anyuhbre, The grass if anything has
died out during 'the drought they have had. rlverythlng is burnt to a c
Pcinderl ang think ass amazing the cattle look as well as they do. They
have not Q, ne di yet. They are fed hay every day and so look O.K. 
Walter says he understands the planting as he is the one 
that has done the work all along.As he needs an other hand I hope Bingley
is return will be alright. I feel that as it was Platt and not you that
fired him that perhaps it would be' alrighf. he is good and handy with  
tools and can meand things. ----- '? Maybe could put him in the gate 
_house ? what dp you think?
We hope to kill the Sectionmen's houses being moved on  
our road and I think we can. We shall lock the gate so they can not use
the road and then let Nature take its course.
[End Page 1]
2
I had a phone call from Liola Armour to-day so I shall see
Lester soon. They are staying at the Anchorage and caan not wait to see
him and hear all about you. 
Darling please let me remind you and hound you somemore about
those photos.I was so dissappointed to just find a picture of a crumppled
bed,and one of Morris with a cigar. Where are the ones of you-'YOU- and
a few of the beach? You promised them to me- please. I want them`so. YOU
tell me you have a large tummie and that your belt is tight over it.I
hope you look well and feel well my darling. How is that old back of yours?
I often think of bt and those ghastly falls at Harford when you put
it out. Such a mistake that hunting was. In fact as you say you have
really done so many nasty things that you hated doing that   immagine -
work in Hawaii is pretty nice by oomparison.I am sure you enjoy the _
accomplishment,and sense of doing something,that you have always wanted.
I guess I was gust born without that ambition as i never want
to see a desk again when get through this war. This time ets reverse
the picture and if you want a desk lige lets live it that way,beoause
for I5 years you have done it my way nd now 1 am beginning to learn
disg glin -doing things _ hate doing,and being places hate being,and
doi eAanyway. My i thought the birds, the trees, the blue skye A
was heaven. I lay on.a matress all one afternoon in the sunshine and
wqtohed the big white puffy cloudssadng across the skye and merge together.
Fortunately the U111s would just take little stroles and return at tea
time and they too enjoyed the bluebirds and the oardinels, the sqnirrells
and the lizards. We saw a coon with his tail staright up in the air paddling
down a road ahead of us completely oblivious to everything. We saw dear
hand turkey but no quail. I was truly yorry it could not have been_4 days
longer as everything was about to burst open at the end of that week of
warm weather and sunshine, and you know how the British appreciate flwers-
-they love them.
' I am afraid I was unable to talk racing with the Field Marshal
which I think surprised hlm,for ofcourse with Seargent Murphy in the family
they believe you should know eberything.-Also my memory is rotten when I
try and recall the names of th places we had in England etc etc. l really
have no memory at all. I am asgmed of it. They both loved riding Qevorcée
and thought her sweet and such nice manners. Uld "dam was charming, and
told us all about the weather forcast and pointed to his dog on the stable
roof that he consults. All the negroes asked about you and want to be 
remembered to you.Mr and Mrs Lowndes, Mr Mrs Kittredge and old Nanny Tiffany. 
also talked and asked and wanted to be remembered yo you both.
If old Medway stands up inspite of its ceiling cracks, wall cracks 
and continual process of disintergration we will be able to go there
and relax and think aboutwwhat we want to do with our lives when this 
war finally is all over. 1 think it should be kept as a simple place, 
and our good furniture taken elsewhere. Qc much becomes unglued and 
spoiled in that dampness and I believe "edwqy should be run by the happy
care free easy going negroes and the only thing we should struggle over 
is a lawn. Shall I try having that lawn reseeded this year with permanent
grass if I can get lt. Its just plane earth except for a patch in front
of the porch. '  
I payed my income tax both federal and State. The Staete 
one as last year in Colombia. George Buist said I should pay my federal
in Colombia next year too. The Guaranty had handled yours Loomis Sayles
has bought and sold somemore for you. They have notifyed you also.
Good-bye until to-morrow- you- Gertie who sends all her love.
[End Page 2]
